abstracts.cdata!:
The three audits represent OED's
            effort to broaden its customary project audit format to
            include an analysis of the adequacy of the World Bank's
            sector assistance. Besides analyzing each project, the
            cluster audit identifies constraints and recipes for success
            that could apply to the entire Indonesian water supply and
            sewerage sector. The performance audit report demonstrates
            that the focus of future assistance should aim at creating
            appropriate sector legislation, regulation, and policies.
            Such a policy-based assistance strategy would improve the
            development and impact of future lending and reach the
            smaller municipalities where the needs are the greatest. OED
            rates the Second Jabotabek Urban Development Project
            satisfactory, its institutional development impact modest,
            sustainability unlikely, and both Bank and Borrowr
            performance satisfactory. The rating of the
            Semarang-Surakarta Urban Development Project is problematic
            since the two project cities differed widely in all aspects.
            In the weighted summary rating, OED rates the outcome of the
            Semarang-Surakarta project moderately unsatisfactory, its
            institutional development impact modest, sustainability
            unlikely, Bank performance satisfactory, and Borrower
            performance unsatisfactory. Finally, OED rates the outcome
            of the Water Supply and Sanitation in Low-Income Communities
            project satisfactory, its institutional development impact
            substantial, sustainability likely, and both Bank and
            Borrower performances satisfactory.
